awd_titl_txt: A Census of Mass-Transfer, Merger, and Collision Products in Old Open Clusters
awd_abstract_narration:
Emily Leiner is awarded an NSF Astronomy and Astrophysics Postdoctoral Fellowship to conduct a program of research and education at Northwestern University.  Nearly half of the stars similar to the Sun exist in binary star systems.  Leiner will study hundreds of binary stars within ?open clusters?, or groups of stars similar in age and composition.  This study will yield an extensive and well characterized sample of binary stars that could help advance our understanding of binary stellar evolution.  Alongside this research, Leiner will work with local high school students through an outreach program at Northwestern, and she will conduct public outreach at the Adler Planetarium.

Leiner will perform a census of post-interaction binary stars on the main sequence and giant branches of five open clusters ranging in age from 2.5 to 8 billion years.  She will identify these stars using rotation rates derived from light curves and extensive radial velocity catalogs.  In addition, she will identify exceedingly massive stars from their oscillation frequencies and determine their masses and radii using asteroseismic techniques.  Leiner will use this new census to constrain formation rates and lifetimes for these post-interaction populations, as well as to investigate the physics that sets these rates and lifetimes.  Leiner will also engage Chicago-area high school students to produce 3D-printed models of oscillating red giant stars and interacting binary systems, and she will use these models to enhance the learning experience of visitors to the Adler Planetarium.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to study binary star systems that result from mass transfer and/or other binary interactions, in particular blue straggler-white dwarf binaries and related stars. To do this, I combined observations of the stellar populations of star clusters with detailed binary evolution modeling and stellar population modeling. The overall goal was to better understand the physics of binary interactions, particularly mass transfer. This mass-transfer process creates many important astrophysical objects including the Type Ia supernovae used to measure the accelerating expansion of our universe, gravitational wave sources that can now be detected with current and future gravitational wave detectors, and other explosive transients we are just starting to observe in large time-domain surveys. Understanding mass-transfer therefore has important implications across many areas of astrophysics. 

The main results of this study are as follows: 

1) We demonstrated that stars spin up to very rapid rotation rates during mass transfer, and then slowly spin down in a predictable way. This makes it possible to use rotation periods of stars to identify stars that have recently been through mass transfer. 

2) We used the above result to discover a new type of post-mass-transfer binary system called a "blue lurker." These stars have been through mass transfer but are relatively low mass, and so they masquerade as "normal" stars. Using rotation, we can now identify these low-mass analogs to the blue straggler stars for the first time. 

3) We completed a large membership study of 16 star clusters using data from the Gaia mission.We assembled a catalog of blue and yellow straggler stars, and compared the observed populations to theoretical models of the these clusters. We demonstrated that theoretical models dramatically underpredict the number of post-mass-transfer binaries that survive as blue/yellow stragglers or blue lurkers, illustrating the need to improve these models significantly. 

4) We demonstrated through detailed binary evolution modeling that the mass-transfer process that creates blue straggler stars and related objects is likely highly non-conservative. This is generally not considered in mass-transfer modeling, which may be one important shortcoming that explains the tension between models and observations of post-mass-transfer binaries. 

5) We showed through observations and modeling of an unusual type of binary system called sub-subgiants that magnetic fields and rotation may have a dramatic impact on the stellar structure of giant stars. 

 

For broader impact work, we created 3D printed models and data visualizations to use at the Adler Planetarium Space Visualization Lab. When the Adler closed during the pandemic, we pivoted to giving virtual talks to amateur astronomy clubs and local students using some of the same data visualization tools. 


Last Modified: 11/14/2023
Modified by: Emily Leiner
